question.Q: Have your periods always been heavy?
Have your periods become heavier in recent months?
Did your periods become heavier after an intrauterine device (IUD) was inserted?
Call your doctor. Heavier periods are a common side effect of IUDS.
Have your periods become more painful?
Is the pain worse toward the end of a period?
See your doctor. You may have a disorder of the pelvic organs such as ENDOMETRIOSIS. Would you like to see symptoms associated with PAINFUL PERIODS?
You may have a disorder of the pelvic organs such as ENDOMETRIOSIS.
Do you have a vaginal discharge between periods that is unusually heavy or that has an unpleasant odor, or is your temperature 100 ℉ ( 37.8 ℃ ) or higher?
See your doctor. You may have an infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissues.
See your doctor. may have a benign growth in the uterus.
Have you had only one heavy period that was a week or more late?
See your doctor. A delayed period can be heavier than usual and is seldom a cause for concern. However, if there is a possibility that you were pregnant, you could have had an early MISCARRIAGE.
Have you recently started to have a few days of light bleeding at the beginning or end of a period?
See your doctor. These symptoms are common as women approach MENOPAUSE. However, they can also be symptoms of FIBROIDS or POLYCYSTIC OVARIAN SYNDROME.
Have you recently had a baby?
Talk to your doctor. The first period after childbirth is often heavier than usual.
See your doctor if you are unable to make a diagnosis from this chat.
See your doctor. Your heavy periods are probably not a cause for concern, but you are at risk of IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA from heavy blood loss.
Did your periods become heavier after an intrauterine device (IUD) was inserted?
Call your doctor. Heavier periods are a common side effect of IUDS.
Have your periods become more painful?
Is the pain worse toward the end of a period?
See your doctor. You may have a disorder of the pelvic organs such as ENDOMETRIOSIS. Would you like to see symptoms associated with PAINFUL PERIODS?

See your doctor. You may have an infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissues.
